doc.field: High water dangerous despite slight easing

Germany's high water problem remains critical. Water levels in the Rhine and lower Mosel valleys are especially high. Flooding from the Main and Tauber rivers have put the old part of the city of Wertheim, Baden-Wurttemberg under water last night. The water level of the Rhine River in Cologne rose above the 9-meter mark early this morning. Agencies in Bavaria, Hesse, and Lower Saxony reported only occasional flooding of basements along rivers. The German weather service in Offenbach predicts more new precipiation for tomorrow.
SPD solicits all parties' approval of Rau

The SPD wants to win the approval of all parties for the election of Johannes Rau for President. SPD head Lafontaine made the announcement today after Rau's nomination. "Because of his personality and his experience, Rau is the right candidate," said Lafontaine. It is more than unlikely that Rau will be the only candidate to succeed Roman Herzog. It seems certain however that Herzog will not be running for a second term. There are no doubts that Rau will be elected the second social-democratic President. The red-green coalition also has a solid majority in the Presidential Election Council.
Government wants less allowance of paying off unemployment benefits

The red-green coalition government plans improvement on paying off unemployment. It wants to partially reduce the allowances for paying unemployment benefits, as State Secretary Mr Andres of the Federal Work Ministry told BILD newspaper.
Germany and Great Britain begin mutual efforts

Germany and Great Britain want to cooperatively seek options for better connections between economic growth and social justice. German Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder and British Prime Minister Tony Blaire explained in London that a standing committee should be put in charge of this question. Mr Schroeder emphasized that monetary politics must contribute to the reduction of unemployment. Neither Mr Schroeder nor Mr Blaire included the independence of the issuing banks in the discussion.
Schroeder: new framework for international financial markets

Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder has called for a new framework for the international financial markets in light of the crises in Russia and Asia. In Birmingham, England, he said the governments of the EU countries have to formulate new rules in order to make such problems unlikely in the future. Before the British Employers Association, Mr Schroeder further explained that the world economy needs a new framework that guides the behavior of private participants, corporations, and banks down the right paths.

The German Industry and Trade Association (DIHT) expects a slightly weakened growth rate of 2.5% for 1999. The prognosis of 3% for the current year will remain, said Association leader Mr Schose in Bonn, at the presentation of the Association's fall survey. Mr Schose emphasized that most of the 25,000 companies surveyed were anxious that the burden on business would grow. The economy will have to wait for the concrete decisions of the red-green coalition government.

The Agreement for Education, drafted by the first red-red state government in Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania, has been settled. The Social Democrats (SPD) and the Democratic Socialists (PDS, the former communists in East-Germany) signed the agreement today in Schwerin. It provides the establishment of a publicly supported work creation scheme, and the abolition of the routine review of public servants to whether they have cooperated with the Stasi, the former East German secret service.

After the renewed gain in the German stock exchange, numerous market participants expect that the interim rise will end soon. One broker said that investors are becoming very careful. Financial advice is not as easily trusted. Many investors have passed up riding the rapid gain, and are waiting for lower rates.
